Clinical: Eyes, heavy. Hearing, illusions of. Hemiplegia. Numbness. Tongue, paralysis of. Vertigo. Vision, disordered.
Characteristics: Coniin. is a poison rivalling prussic acid in the intensity of action. It has had rather an extensive proving. It causes numbness, muscular paralysis, vertigo, disorders of sight, hearing, and touch, lethargy and overpowering sleepiness. A feeling as if one had been up all night, or after a debauch. Cramp in calves on ascending steps or drawing off boots. Vertigo is > in open air.
Mind: Calm and tranquil; slowness of mental process.
Inability to think or fix the attention.
Head: Vertigo and confusion with prostration > in open air.
Weight, fulness, and pressure in head.
Open air caused pain in supra-orbital and cutaneous malae nerves.
Eyes: Objects seem large; one thinks he sees his own nose a shapeless mass.
Ears: Hearing weakened; ears feel as if stopped with cotton wool.
Face: Numbness of muscles about the jaws.
Mouth: Epithelium denuded in many places, papillae very prominent.
Respiratory Organs: Voice thick; muddled words when speaking.
Neck and Back: Spasmodic distortion of neck with spasms of face which draw the mouth up to a point.
Limbs: Heaviness of arms and legs, esp. l. arm.
Upper Limbs: Tense cramp in muscles of ball of thumb with painful sensation on strongly adducting thumb.
Lower Limbs: Gait unsteady; weakness esp. marked on going out to walk.
Legs felt independent as if they did not care for him or anybody else.
Cramp in calves on ascending steps.
